Authors:
Akihiko Kinoshita, Kazuhide Nara, Hiromi Sasaki, Keisuke
obase, Bang Feng, Zhu-Liang Yang
Title:
Using mating-type loci to improve taxonomy of the Tuber
indicum complex and discovery of a new species, T. longispinosum
Keywords: biogeography, black truffle, cryptic species, MAT
Abstract:
Black truffles that morphologically resemble Tuber indicum
have been known to occur in Japan since 1979. Our previous studies
showed that there are two phylotypes of these truffles, both of which
fell into the T. indicum complex. However, their taxonomic treatment is
still unclear. In this study, we conducted morphological and
phylogenetic analyses for a total of 43 specimens that originated from
Japan (10 each for two Tuber taxa described hereafter as Tuber sp. 6 and
Tuber sp. 7), China (10 T. himalayense and eight T. indicum), and Taiwan
Island, China (five T. formosanum). We compared ascospore ornamentation,
size, distribution of asci with different number of spores, spine
height, and spine bases of the Japanese specimens with their allied
taxa. For phylogenetic analysis, we sequenced two mating loci (MAT1-1-1
and MAT1-2-1) and three commonly used loci. Three distinct lineages were
recognized by phylogenetic analyses based on the sequences of the two
mating-related loci and three mating-unrelated loci. The Tuber sp. 6
sequences clustered with those of T. himalayense and T. formosanum, and
there was no clear difference in morphology among them. Tuber sp. 7
formed a monophyletic clade in each phylogram. The taxa tended to have
five-spored asci more frequently than other allied taxa and could be
characterized as having ascospore ornamentation with longer spines and
narrower spine bases. We therefore described Tuber sp. 7 as a new
species (T. longispinosum), and treated Tuber sp. 6 and T. formosanum as
synonyms of T. himalayense.
